docs.abstract: At Tuesday night’s Democratic debate, moderators asked some of the candidates about their views on the inquiry in an attempt to find daylight between them.
docs.snippet: At Tuesday night’s Democratic debate, moderators asked some of the candidates about their views on the inquiry in an attempt to find daylight between them.
docs.lead_paragraph: Since Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced last month that the House would initiate a formal impeachment inquiry against President Trump, the topic has dominated the news. At Tuesday night’s Democratic debate, moderators asked the candidates about their views in an attempt to find daylight between them.

headline.main: What Democratic Candidates Said About Impeaching Trump at the Debate

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry

docs.abstract: Twelve Democratic presidential candidates shared the stage in Ohio for the fourth televised primary debate.
docs.snippet: Twelve Democratic presidential candidates shared the stage in Ohio for the fourth televised primary debate.
docs.lead_paragraph: Is it enough to ban the sale of assault weapons or should existing owners also be required to relinquish them under the threat of consequences? The question generated a heated exchange between former Representative Beto O’Rourke of Texas and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., at Tuesday’s Democratic debate.

headline.main: Beto O’Rourke and Pete Buttigieg Battle Over Confiscating Assault Weapons

docs.abstract: The Vermont senator said he would “change the nature” of his campaign. He also acknowledged that voters would take his health into account when deciding whether to support him.
docs.snippet: The Vermont senator said he would “change the nature” of his campaign. He also acknowledged that voters would take his health into account when deciding whether to support him.
docs.lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Senator Bernie Sanders, in a striking concession for a leading presidential candidate, said on Tuesday that he planned to slow down his pace on the campaign trail after suffering a heart attack a week ago, and acknowledged that voters would likely consider his health when deciding whether to support him.

headline.main: Bernie Sanders Says He Will Slow His Campaign Pace After Heart Attack
headline.print_headline: After Heart Attack, Sanders Will Slow Pace of His Campaign

byline.original: By Sydney Ember and Jonathan Martin

docs.abstract: As a leading candidate in an extremely tight race, Mr. Sanders will inevitably face questions about the viability and intensity of his campaign going forward.
docs.snippet: As a leading candidate in an extremely tight race, Mr. Sanders will inevitably face questions about the viability and intensity of his campaign going forward.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Senator Bernie Sanders recuperates from the heart attack he suffered while campaigning last Tuesday in Las Vegas, he will inevitably face questions in the coming days as to whether he will continue his presidential campaign and, if so, at what pace.

headline.main: How Will Bernie Sanders’s Heart Attack Affect His Campaign?
headline.print_headline: Scrutiny for a Front-Runner in a Close Race After a Heart Attack

docs.abstract: “I think we did it appropriately and did it as quickly as we could,” Mr. Sanders said. “No apologies.”
docs.snippet: “I think we did it appropriately and did it as quickly as we could,” Mr. Sanders said. “No apologies.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders acknowledged on Wednesday that he knew he had suffered a heart attack three days before his campaign released that information, but he defended the decision to keep those details private.

headline.main: Bernie Sanders Says He Knew of Heart Attack Three Days Before Disclosing It
headline.print_headline: Sanders Defends Delay  In Sharing Health News

byline.original: By Maggie Astor and Sydney Ember

docs.abstract: They signed open letters, dedicated a special magazine issue to criticism of him and swore he would tear at the fabric of this nation. Now they have become the president’s strongest defenders.
docs.snippet: They signed open letters, dedicated a special magazine issue to criticism of him and swore he would tear at the fabric of this nation. Now they have become the president’s strongest defenders.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2016, Erick Erickson could not have been clearer. Donald Trump was “a racist” and “a fascist.” It was no wonder, Mr. Erickson wrote, that “so many people with swastikas in their Twitter profile pics” supported him. “I will not vote for Donald Trump. Ever,” he insisted, adding his voice to the chorus of Never Trump Republicans.

headline.main: The ‘Never Trump’ Coalition That Decided Eh, Never Mind, He’s Fine
headline.print_headline: A ‘Never Trump’ Coalition’s New Point of View: Never Mind, He’s Fine

docs.abstract: After mass shootings jolted the nation this month, the Democratic candidates seemed to move in lock step toward more aggressive gun control positions without resistance from moderates.
docs.snippet: After mass shootings jolted the nation this month, the Democratic candidates seemed to move in lock step toward more aggressive gun control positions without resistance from moderates.
docs.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Democrats running for president have engaged in bitter disputes this year over topics like health care, immigration and criminal justice.

headline.main: On Gun Control, 2020 Democrats Agree: No Reason to Hold Back
headline.print_headline: Bullish on Gun Control, Democrats Compete Over Who Can Sell It Best

byline.original: By Reid J. Epstein and Thomas Kaplan

docs.abstract: In the wake of the mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America.
docs.snippet: In the wake of the mass shootings in El Paso and Dayton, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America.
docs.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — One by one, Democratic presidential candidates on Saturday emphasized the urgent need to confront gun violence in America, speaking largely in harmony on an issue that has been thrust to the forefront after last weekend’s mass shootings in El Paso and in Dayton, Ohio.

headline.main: Democrats in Iowa Offer Plans to Combat Gun Violence
headline.print_headline: In Combating Gun Violence, Democrats Present a United Front

docs.abstract: Mr. Hickenlooper, who has remained near the bottom of the Democratic field, is in discussions to challenge Colorado’s Republican senator, Cory Gardner.
docs.snippet: Mr. Hickenlooper, who has remained near the bottom of the Democratic field, is in discussions to challenge Colorado’s Republican senator, Cory Gardner.
docs.lead_paragraph: [Update: John Hickenlooper said that he’s officially ending his presidential campaign.]

headline.main: John Hickenlooper Mulling Ending Presidential Bid to Run for Senate
headline.print_headline: Hickenlooper, Mired in Polls, May Abandon His Campaign

docs.abstract: After months of putting the state on the back-burner, Ms. Harris has stepped up her presence in Iowa, spending more days there in recent weeks than she did through June.
docs.snippet: After months of putting the state on the back-burner, Ms. Harris has stepped up her presence in Iowa, spending more days there in recent weeks than she did through June.
docs.lead_paragraph: STORM LAKE, Iowa — Senator Kamala Harris ordered tacos at a Mexican joint in Storm Lake (two chicken, one pork). She mingled with the masses at a New York-themed bar in Sioux City. (“You’ve got the whitest teeth,” one patron told her. “That’s a plus right there.”) She sampled apple egg rolls and flipped pork chops at the Iowa State Fair in Des Moines.

headline.main: Kamala Harris, in a Pivot, Makes Her Play for Iowa
headline.print_headline: In Iowa, a Bid to Make Up for Lost Time

byline.original: By Shane Goldmacher and Maddie McGarvey
